pico.title: Privacy-Enhancing Technologies for Geospatial Biodiversity Data Sharing: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Geospatial species occurrence datasets shared by biodiversity monitoring organizations, including citizen science platforms, national biodiversity databases, GBIF-mediated data, and sensitive species location records used in conservation planning and ecological research
pico.intervention: Privacy-enhancing technologies including spatial generalization (grid-based aggregation, convex hulls), differential privacy mechanisms, controlled access systems (tiered permissions, data use agreements), spatial cloaking, k-anonymity adaptations for location data, and emerging approaches such as secure multi-party computation and zero-knowledge proofs for data governance
pico.comparison: Alternative PET approaches compared against each other, against unprotected data sharing baselines, and across different parameterizations (e.g., grid resolutions, epsilon values, access tier structures)
pico.outcome: Privacy protection effectiveness (re-identification risk, formal privacy guarantees), preservation of ecological analytical utility (species distribution model accuracy, biodiversity index reliability, spatial pattern retention), implementation feasibility (computational cost, regulatory compliance, organizational adoption barriers), and documented trade-offs between privacy and utility
pico.research_question: In geospatial species occurrence datasets, how do different privacy-enhancing technologies compare to each other and to unprotected sharing in terms of privacy guarantee strength, preservation of ecological analytical utility, and implementation feasibility for biodiversity monitoring organizations?
pico.rationale: Biodiversity monitoring organizations face a critical dilemma: sharing species occurrence data enables research and conservation action, but exposing precise locations of endangered, commercially valuable, or culturally sensitive species creates risks including poaching, illegal collection, and habitat disturbance. GDPR and similar regulations add compliance requirements when human activity patterns are captured alongside biodiversity observations. Despite growing literature on privacy-preserving geospatial methods, no systematic synthesis exists to guide practitioners in selecting appropriate PETs for biodiversity contexts. This scoping review maps validated approaches, identifies evidence gaps, and characterizes trade-offs to support evidence-based technology selection.

sub_questions.title: Spatial Generalization Effectiveness
sub_questions.population: Species point occurrence records from citizen science platforms and national databases
sub_questions.intervention: Spatial generalization methods (grid-based aggregation at various resolutions, adaptive grids, convex hull masking)
sub_questions.comparison: Original point data versus generalized outputs at 1km, 10km, 50km resolutions; fixed versus adaptive grid approaches
sub_questions.outcome: Species distribution model accuracy (AUC, TSS), location privacy (k-anonymity achievement, re-identification risk), spatial pattern preservation
sub_questions.research_question: For citizen science species occurrence records, how does grid-based spatial generalization at different resolutions compare to original point data in preserving species distribution model accuracy while reducing re-identification risk?

sub_questions.title: Differential Privacy for Biodiversity Statistics
sub_questions.population: Aggregated biodiversity metrics derived from occurrence data (species richness, abundance indices, diversity measures)
sub_questions.intervention: Differential privacy mechanisms (Laplace noise, Gaussian mechanism, exponential mechanism) applied to biodiversity statistics
sub_questions.comparison: Different epsilon (Îµ) values ranging from 0.1 to 10; comparison to unprotected statistics baseline
sub_questions.outcome: Statistical accuracy of biodiversity indices, formal privacy guarantee strength, utility-privacy trade-off curves
sub_questions.research_question: For aggregated biodiversity metrics, how do differential privacy mechanisms with varying epsilon values compare to unprotected statistics in maintaining accuracy of diversity indices while providing formal privacy guarantees?

sub_questions.title: Access Control versus Data Transformation
sub_questions.population: Sensitive species location data (IUCN threatened species, commercially valuable species, culturally sensitive sites)
sub_questions.intervention: Controlled access systems including tiered permission structures, data use agreements, embargo periods, and institutional vetting
sub_questions.comparison: Data transformation approaches (generalization, perturbation, synthetic data generation)
sub_questions.outcome: Research utility metrics, compliance burden (time, cost, administrative overhead), documented data misuse incidents, researcher satisfaction
sub_questions.research_question: For sensitive species location data, how do controlled access systems compare to data transformation approaches in enabling research utility while minimizing compliance burden and data misuse risk?
